channel.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
channel.description:
Whenever I try to debug a C++ file on Visual C++ 2005 Express Edition, I get an error. If the Solution Configurations are on Debug, and I start Debugging, I get this error.
------ Build started: Project: Shop, Configuration: Debug Win32 ------ Linking... LINK : fatal error LNK1168: cannot open C:\Documents and Settings\john m jennings\My Documents\Visual Studio 2005\Projects\Shop\Debug\Shop.exe for writing Build log was saved at "file://c:\Documents and Settings\john m jennings\My Documents\Visual Studio 2005\Projects\Shop\Debug\BuildLog.htm" Shop - 1 error(s), 0 warning(s) ========== Build: 0 succeeded, 1 failed, 0 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========
And if I have it on release to generate a .bat file (Which I wanted), I get this error.
------ Build started: Project: Shop, Configuration: Release Win32 ------ Compiling... stdafx.cpp Compiling... Shop.cpp Linking... Generating code Finished generating code Embedding manifest... Project : error PRJ0003 : Error spawning 'cmd.exe'. Build log was saved at "file://c:\Documents and Settings\john m jennings\My Documents\Visual Studio 2005\Projects\Shop\Release\BuildLog.htm" Shop - 1 error(s), 0 warning(s) ========== Build: 0 succeeded, 1 failed, 0 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========
Now, last night I was at my cousin's house. He had a way earlier version of the Microsoft C++ program, and I used it. I managed to actually make a working batch file, and everything would be right. I had in this code (All I can remember right now). [code]#include "stdafx.h" main() { int money; printf("Input the amount of money you want.\n"); scanf("$%d\n", money); money = %d; printf("Money increased.\n"); getchar(); }[/code] Now, if I put that in there, I get an error. That worked fine on the other. So, two questions. 1. Did the Microsoft C++ Program thing that was from 1995 or so update/change the C++ language up to the 2005's version? 2. Will someone tell me what's wrong when I try to debug :o Thanks, Lin

item.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
item.dc:creator: @Bookworm9405 Bookworm9405
item.description:
@Bookworm9405 wrote:

You really shoulden’t use Microsoft anything, that’s true. Use Dev-C++, or Borland.

And yes, you should check to make sure that the .exe file for the program isn’t already running, or running and not responding. I don’t think it would let you compile if it was, but then I don’t use Visual C++ often.

Read full topic
item.source: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file

item.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

When you click debug, it makes a batch file as the program.

Huh? I still don’t get it. What does the batch file do?

Read full topic
item.source: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file

item.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Javacisnotrecognized, post:3, topic:104820”]Is the program running? Because you can’t delete an executable while the executable is executing[/quote] No. It did that since the day I first got it (Yesterday).

[quote=“Mopman, post:4, topic:104820”]The only time I’ve had that error is when I wrote a program that didn’t die properly when I closed it (ie went into an infinite loop or for some other reason didn’t close) so when you try to recompile it, the compiler is trying to overwrite the exe, and obviously can’t because it’s still running. Check task manager

What does this have to do with batch files, though?[/quote] When you click debug, it makes a batch file as the program.

And now it says it can’t find the file.exe, so it can’t run.

Read full topic
item.source: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file

item.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

The only time I’ve had that error is when I wrote a program that didn’t die properly when I closed it (ie went into an infinite loop or for some other reason didn’t close) so when you try to recompile it, the compiler is trying to overwrite the exe, and obviously can’t because it’s still running. Check task manager

What does this have to do with batch files, though?

item.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Is the program running? Because you can’t delete an executable while the executable is executing

item.source: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file

item.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

I don’t know what else to use

I used the Microsoft C++ Development 5.0, and I managed to make a crappy program that tells how old you will be in the year you put in from the age you put in. I can’t attatch, because I made at my cousin’s. But I think I remember what it looked like.

[code]#include “stdafx.h”
#define /‘007’/

main()
{

int age;
int year = 2007;
int futureyear;
int added;
int age2;
int finage;

puts(“Welcome to the Agifier!\n”);
puts(“Please put in your age.”);
scanf("%d", &age);
puts(“Now put in the future year.”);
scanf("%d", &futureyear);
added = year + age;
year + age;
age2 = futureyear - added;
futureyear - added;
finage = age2 + age + age;
age2 + age + age;
printf(“You will be %d in the year %d!”, &finage, futureyear);
}[/code] I’m not sure if that was the complete thing, but I made it work. Anyways, where can I get something else to code C++?

Read full topic
item.source: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file

item.title: I always get an error while trying to debug a C++ file
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Whenever I try to debug a C++ file on Visual C++ 2005 Express Edition, I get an error. If the Solution Configurations are on Debug, and I start Debugging, I get this error.

------ Build started: Project: Shop, Configuration: Debug Win32 ------ Linking... LINK : fatal error LNK1168: cannot open C:\Documents and Settings\john m jennings\My Documents\Visual Studio 2005\Projects\Shop\Debug\Shop.exe for writing Build log was saved at "file://c:\Documents and Settings\john m jennings\My Documents\Visual Studio 2005\Projects\Shop\Debug\BuildLog.htm" Shop - 1 error(s), 0 warning(s) ========== Build: 0 succeeded, 1 failed, 0 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========

And if I have it on release to generate a .bat file (Which I wanted), I get this error.

------ Build started: Project: Shop, Configuration: Release Win32 ------ Compiling... stdafx.cpp Compiling... Shop.cpp Linking... Generating code Finished generating code Embedding manifest... Project : error PRJ0003 : Error spawning 'cmd.exe'. Build log was saved at "file://c:\Documents and Settings\john m jennings\My Documents\Visual Studio 2005\Projects\Shop\Release\BuildLog.htm" Shop - 1 error(s), 0 warning(s) ========== Build: 0 succeeded, 1 failed, 0 up-to-date, 0 skipped ==========

Now, last night I was at my cousin’s house. He had a way earlier version of the Microsoft C++ program, and I used it. I managed to actually make a working batch file, and everything would be right. I had in this code (All I can remember right now).

[code]#include “stdafx.h”

main()
{
int money;
printf(“Input the amount of money you want.\n”);
scanf("$%d\n", money);
money = %d;
printf(“Money increased.\n”);
getchar();
}[/code] Now, if I put that in there, I get an error. That worked fine on the other. So, two questions.

  1. Did the Microsoft C++ Program thing that was from 1995 or so update/change the C++ language up to the 2005’s version?
  2. Will someone tell me what’s wrong when I try to debug :o

Thanks,
Lin
